History: The Irish Potato Famine begins spreading rapidly through Ireland launching a wave of Irish immigration to the U.S.
Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo extending citizenship to Mexicans living in newly annexed states. California Gold Rush bringing in immigrants from Mexico, China, Europe, etc.
Rise of the Know-Nothing Party an anti-immigration movement
Adoption of the 14th Amendment in which anyone born in the U.S. would automatically become a U.S. citizen
Supreme Court declares that immigration law will be enforced by the federal government
The Chinese Exclusion Act passes baring Chinese immigrants from entering the U.S.
Immigration Act of 1891 further excluding who can enter the U.S. Add more detail
Ellis Island, the first U.S. immigration station, opens in New York Harbor
Gentlemen's Agreement between the U.S. and Japan which limited Japanese emigration to the U.S in exchange for the end of segragation of Japanese students in San Fransisco schools
Franz Ferdinand and his wife are assassinated sparking the beginning of World War 1
On the eve of American involvement in World War 1, the Immigration Act of 1917 passes halting immigration from many Asian countries and establishing a literacy requirement
Treaty of Versailles is signed ending World War 1
Immigration Act of 1924 introducing a quota system to limit the number of immigrants coming from any single nation while favoring Western and Northern European nations.
Start of the Great Depression
Hitler invades Poland sparking the beginning of World War 2
Bracero Program is formed allowing Mexican workers to enter the U.S. temporarily
Japenese surrender, ending World War 2
Displaced Persons Act passes allowing European refugees affected by World War 2 to resettle in the U.S.
McCarran-Walter Act formally ends the exclusion of Asian immigrants to the U.S.
The U.S. admits Hungarian immigrants which are among the first Cold War refugees
Cuban Revolution
Operation Peter Pan formed as a clandestine mass exodus of over 14,000 unaccompanied Cuban minors
Guatemalan Civil War
Immigration and Nationality Act is passed abolishing the quota system and overhauling the U.S. immigration system
Nicaraguan Revolution
Salvadorian Civil War
The Mariel boatlift starts in which roughly 125,000 cubans cross the sea in overcrowded boats to reach the shores of Florida
Ronald Reagan signs The Immigration Reform and Control Act granting amnesty to more than 3 million immigrantsliving illegally in the U.S.
Immigration Act of 1990 is passed allowing the president to grant a temporary protect status to immigrants from countries afflicted with armed conflict or natural disasters
Dissolution of the Soviet Union into 15 independent Republics
Breakup of Yugoslavia and formation of independent successor states
September 11 atack on the World Trade Center
Creation of the Department of Homeland Security
Secure Fence Act approved $1.2 billion for 700 miles of fence along the U.S.- Mexico border
President Obama issues an executive order known as Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals to hault deportation of young immigrants
